pageProps.body:
Non-Linear Equations

This section studies any general equation of the form

Q(x,y)dydx+P(x,y)=0Q(x, y)\frac{dy}{dx} + P(x,y) = 0Q(x,y)dxdy​+P(x,y)=0

where, if the power of yyy or y′y'y′ is higher than 1, the equation is said to be non-linear. Two cases arise for these equations:

Definition. (Separable equations). This case applies for equations that can be separated into the form f(x)dx=g(y)dyf(x) dx = g(y) dyf(x)dx=g(y)dy, making the equation relatively simple as both sides can simply be integrated. For instance, the equation (3x+2)dydx=y(3x+2)\frac{dy}{dx} = y(3x+2)dxdy​=y can be separated into dyy=dx3x+2\frac{dy}{y} = \frac{dx}{3x+2}ydy​=3x+2dx​, with each side containing one variable only.

Definition. (Exact equations). (Exact equations). We define a DE in the form Q(x,y)dydx+P(x,y)=0Q(x,y)\frac{dy}{dx} + P(x,y) = 0Q(x,y)dxdy​+P(x,y)=0 to be exact if and only if there is a function f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) such that ∂f∂x=P(x,y)\frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = P(x,y)∂x∂f​=P(x,y) and ∂f∂y=Q(x,y)\frac{\partial f}{\partial y} = Q(x,y)∂y∂f​=Q(x,y); that is, if Q(x,y)Q(x,y)Q(x,y) is one partial derivative of fff and PPP is the other partial derivative.

Alternatively, if the equation is rewritten Q(x,y)dy+P(x,y)dx=0Q(x,y) dy + P(x,y) dx = 0Q(x,y)dy+P(x,y)dx=0, it is exact if and only if there is a function f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) such that df=P dx+Q dydf = P\ dx + Q\ dydf=P dx+Q dy.

To check whether a DE is exact, notice that mixed second derivatives are equal (fxy=fyxf_{xy} = f_{yx}fxy​=fyx​); thus, if PPP and QQQ are both partial derivatives of the same function fff, then PyP_yPy​ = QxQ_xQx​. This method only holds if the domain of fff is simply-connected.

Definition. Simply-connected domain. A domain D\mathbf{D}D is simply-connected if:

  1. The domain is connected (closed) and not open.
  2. Any closed loop in D\mathbf{D}D can be shrunk to a point that is still on D\mathbf{D}D.

For instance, a sphere is simply-connected while a donut is not. Yum!

Theorem. If ∂P∂y=∂Q∂x\frac{\partial P}{\partial y} = \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x}∂y∂P​=∂x∂Q​ through a simply-connected domain D\mathbf{D}D, then the differential equation Qy′+P=0Qy' + P = 0Qy′+P=0 is exact.

Method. (Solving exact differential equations).

If it is known that df=P dx+Q dydf = P\ dx + Q\ dydf=P dx+Q dy, then f(x,y)=λf(x,y) = \lambdaf(x,y)=λ for some constant λ\lambdaλ is a solution to the DE. In order to find fff, we integrate ∂f∂x=P\frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = P∂x∂f​=P with respect to xxx, giving a function plus a function depending only on yyy (due to yyy being held constant in the partial derivative).

This result can then be differentiated with respect to yyy to obtain ∂f∂y+h′(y)=Q+h′(y)\frac{\partial f}{\partial y} + h'(y) = Q + h'(y)∂y∂f​+h′(y)=Q+h′(y), which can be compared to QQQ to obtain h′(y)h'(y)h′(y). This can be best illustrated with the following example.

Example. Find the general solution to 6y(y−x)dydx+(2x−3y2)=06y(y-x)\frac{dy}{dx} + (2x-3y^2) = 06y(y−x)dxdy​+(2x−3y2)=0.

Solution.

Set Q=6y(y−x),P=2x−3y2Q = 6y(y-x), P= 2x-3y^2Q=6y(y−x),P=2x−3y2. Then Py=−6y=QxP_y = -6y = Q_xPy​=−6y=Qx​, meaning that the differential form is exact. First integrate PPP with respect to xxx:

f=∫P dx=∫∂f∂x dx=∫2x−3y2 dx=x2−3xy2+h(y)f = \int P \ dx = \int \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \ dx = \int 2x-3y^2 \ dx =x^2 - 3xy^2 + h(y)f=∫P dx=∫∂x∂f​ dx=∫2x−3y2 dx=x2−3xy2+h(y)

for some function h(y)h(y)h(y) depending only on yyy. Differentiating this with respect to yyy gives

Q+h′(y)=6y2−6xy+h′(y)=−6xyQ + h'(y) =6y^2 - 6xy + h'(y) = -6xyQ+h′(y)=6y2−6xy+h′(y)=−6xy

and thus h′(y)=−6y2,h(y)=−2y3+Ch'(y) = -6y^2, h(y) = -2y^3 + Ch′(y)=−6y2,h(y)=−2y3+C for a constant CCC. The final solution is f=x2−3xy2+h(y)=x2−3xy2−2y3=Cf = x^2 - 3xy^2 + h(y) = x^2 - 3xy^2 - 2y^3 = Cf=x2−3xy2+h(y)=x2−3xy2−2y3=C.
